Literature Review: Neural control of sexually dimorphic social behavior has been a topic of increasing interest in recent years, with advances in the field highlighting the complex interplay between developmental and adult processes. The development of social behavior in mammals is a critical period, influenced by the production of androgens by the fetal testis. This review aims to explore the mechanisms that connect early-life programming to adult behaviors, focusing on four core processes: epigenetics, cell death, circuit formation, and adult hormonal modulation. We also propose that adolescent play plays a crucial role in bridging the preweaning to postpubertal brain, engaging the same neural networks underlying adult reproductive and aggressive behaviors. The following discussion will examine the current state of knowledge on these topics, highlighting the key findings and debates in the field.
